title: Statement by Eugene Walker on hiding emails from FOI

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
And big up to FOI squad!
I've got some requests for recorded information held by the authority in response to the statement by Eugene Walker, in The Star.
https://www.thestar.co.uk/news/politics/...
From the statement:
"In this case, officers marked some emails with the term ‘legally privileged not subject to FOI’ where they considered there might need to be a decision about future disclosure. "
1. Identify and provide any recorded information relied upon by SCC to include this statements where officers were considering "there might need to be a decision about future disclosure."
2. Identify and provide any recorded information where the FOI teams were made aware that this consideration had taken place, and they were aware of this practice.
3. Identify how many officers were part of this consideration "there might need to be a decision about future disclosure.".
From the statement:
"The exemptions used will always be thoroughly scrutinized by the council’s internal FOI team when handling these requests"
Please refer to your response to the ICO in case FS50745686
And make familiar with the email: RE: Release of schedule 2 (legal privilege applies exempt from FOI) 02 March 2018 06:35
This email would have matched recorded information sought in FS50745686.
4. Please provide from  FS5074568 the request for information sent out from the FOI team to relevant departments and the responses received back with information held.
5. Identify and provide recorded information related to the scrutiny of email: RE: Release of schedule 2 (legal privilege applies exempt from FOI) 02 March 2018 06:35 in relation to  FS5074568
-------
Yours faithfully,
Marcus Combie

Dear FOI,
Please either a decision notice so I can request an internal review and then escalate to the ICO.
This request was submitted on the 10th of March.
The request is related to recorded information sought in Mr Buxton’s request: your ref  1879.  This request was submitted on the 10th of March too.
https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/s...
A response was issued to Mr Buxton on the 4th of September. The information used to support the press statement has clearly been identified.
The press statement also state “ thoroughly scrutinized by the council’s internal FOI team” one would expect with through scrutinization there would be also thorough documentation of scruitiny process.
As the process was conducted by “the internal FOI team” then documents should be readily available to the FOI team as they are the custodians, especially in relation to the ICO investigation.
Please provide the current status of this request.
The requestor does not accept that an additional four weeks is necessary. The council was able to come up with this statement in a matter of days in response to a news article. As such the council should have readily available the documents used to support the position in the press statement.
Yours sincerely,
Marcus Combie

Dear Mr Combie
Thank you for your request for information which we received on 10 March
2020 relating to the statement issued by the Council and included in an
article in The Star on 10 March 2020. Please accept our apologies for the
delay in our response.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request set out
below:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
And big up to FOI squad!
I've got some requests for recorded information held by the authority in
response to the statement by Eugene Walker, in The Star.
[1]
https://www.thestar.co.uk/news/politics/...
From the statement:
"In this case, officers marked some emails with the term ‘legally
privileged not subject to FOI’ where they considered there might need to
be a decision about future disclosure. "
1. Identify and provide any recorded information relied upon by SCC to
include this statements where officers were considering "there might need
to be a decision about future disclosure."
Please see the attached email.
Please note that we consider that the exemption under section 42 of the
Freedom of Information Act 2000 applies to this email as it is covered by
legal professional privilege. However, on application of the public
interest test, we believe that the public interest lies in favour of
disclosure. While we recognise that it is important to protect the concept
of legal professional privilege and the rationale behind the concept,
which is to safeguard frankness between lawyer and client, we also
recognise that there is a public interest in openness and transparency,
which in this case, is more important than maintaining protecting the
concept of privilege. Therefore, we have disclosed the email.
However, please note that the names of  some staff members have been
redacted under section 40(2) of the Freedom of Information Act 2000 on the
grounds that these are personal data and disclosure would contravene the
data protection principle under Article 5(1)(a) of the General Data
Protection Regulation that processing of personal data must be fair,
lawful and transparent.
2. Identify and provide any recorded information where the FOI teams were
made aware that this consideration had taken place, and they were aware of
this practice.
3. Identify how many officers were part of this consideration "there might
need to be a decision about future disclosure.".
Officers in Legal Services were instructed to mark emails as legally
privileged and not subject to FOI in order to flag to officers in the
Information Management Team that these emails might be legally privileged.
This title acted as a flag to help officers filter out information which
might need to be redacted prior to disclosure. However, just because an
email was entitled “legally privileged – not subject to FOI”, this would
not automatically mean that we would refuse to disclose it. Officers in
the Information Management Team review all correspondence before it is
disclosed under FOI, and this frequently requires them to challenge
services about the application of exemptions. Any information which a
service has suggested is exempt is always reviewed to ensure that an
exemption under FOIA is actually applicable to the information, and any
information which is not exempt is disclosed. All officers in the
Information Management Team are familiar with the exemptions under FOIA
and are aware of the need to ensure that any exemptions are applied
lawfully when responding to FOI requests.
From the statement:
"The exemptions used will always be thoroughly scrutinized by the
council’s internal FOI team when handling these requests"
Please refer to your response to the ICO in case FS50745686
And make familiar with the email: RE: Release of schedule 2 (legal
privilege applies exempt from FOI) 02 March 2018 06:35
This email would have matched recorded information sought in FS50745686.
4. Please provide from  FS5074568 the request for information sent out
from the FOI team to relevant departments and the responses received back
with information held.
Please find the relevant emails attached. Please note that the names of
current staff members at a more junior level, former staff members, and
third parties have been redacted under section 40(2) of the Freedom of
Information Act 2000 on the grounds that these are personal data and
disclosure would contravene the data protection principle under Article
5(1)(a) of the General Data Protection Regulation that processing of
personal data must be fair, lawful and transparent.
5. Identify and provide recorded information related to the scrutiny of
email: RE: Release of schedule 2 (legal privilege applies exempt from FOI)
02 March 2018 06:35 in relation to  FS5074568
We do not hold any information about the scrutiny of this email.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [2]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by either writing to the above address or by emailing
[3][Sheffield City Council request email]. Internal review requests should be submitted
within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[4]www.ico.org.uk for further details.
Kind Regards,
Robert Jackson
Access to Information Officer
Information Management Team
Business Change and Information Solutions
Resources Portfolio
Sheffield City Council

Dear FOI,
Thanks for your reply! Apologies in advance for the length of this. I've included some details the FOI team may already be aware of, but if this request is escalated to the ICO I felt having context and relevant materials inline would be beneficial.
Please consider this a request for an internal review.
****************
I don’t see a response for the second element of my request. If it’s the response also included under #3 then please include the following for the internal review.
Officers in Legal Services were instructed to mark emails as legally
privileged and not subject to FOI in order to flag to officers in the
Information Management Team that these emails might be legally privileged.
This title acted as a flag to help officers filter out information which
might need to be redacted prior to disclosure. However, just because an
email was entitled “legally privileged – not subject to FOI”, this would
not automatically mean that we would refuse to disclose it. Officers in
the Information Management Team review all correspondence before it is
disclosed under FOI, and this frequently requires them to challenge
services about the application of exemptions. Any information which a
service has suggested is exempt is always reviewed to ensure that an
exemption under FOIA is actually applicable to the information, and any
information which is not exempt is disclosed. All officers in the
Information Management Team are familiar with the exemptions under FOIA
and are aware of the need to ensure that any exemptions are applied
lawfully when responding to FOI requests.
FOI  - this sounds suspiciously like a press statement or a line to take statement. It does not appear as if it were a response to provide recorded information. I have two objections to the response.
FIRST OBJECTION
The requestor would be seeking in the internal review the FOI teams response here and apparently totally normal process. But in private, the FOI team seemed to be completely oblivious this action was taking place or was standard operation procedure. I refer the council to the following email.
—————————————————
From: <REDACTED> on Behalf of FOI
Sent: 06 December 2019 14:30
To: <REDCATED> CC:<REDACTED>
Subject: RE FOI 116 Operation Quito
Attachments RE: FOI 116 Internal Review 1 of 2;  FOI 116 Internal Review 2 of 2;   Please see attached.  Please note that although some of the emails are entitled “legally privileged - not subject to FOIA” there were not legally privileged and we cannot declare something not subject to FOIA.  Please feel free to call me if you have any queries
————————————————
The email provided by Steve Eccleston that seems to have post hoc feeling. Mr Ecclestons email was sent 18 February 2020, after the FOI team informing <redacted> and <redacted> on 06 December 2019.
Request FOI 116, was a request I made, in that request the council initially told me 4 documents were held, 2 of which were forwarded press statements for SYP… I informed SCC of 7 documents missing from disclosure (That I knew of)
The FOI team replied that :
“I have contacted the officers involved at the time and they have confirmed they don’t hold any further information on this.”
Multiple council officer who are either senders or recipients of the comms with ‘Not subject to FOI’ still work in council, eg head of highways, I imagine it’s hard for “Officers in the Information Management Team review all correspondence before it is disclosed under FOI”. If it has not been disclosed to them and the departments reply back “they don’t hold any further information on this.” It was only after I pointed out the apparent absurdity of planning a three agency meeting including the police on multiple days… and only have 4 documents to provide, most of which were after the meetings. Did more documents come to light.
“Officers in Legal Services were instructed to mark emails as legally
privileged and not subject to FOI in order to flag to officers in the
Information Management Team” this is what the council is claiming. However in RE: Release of schedule 2 (legal privilege applies exempt from FOI) 02 March 2018 06:35 this email was about an SCC press release, the prior emails in this chain were not marked “legal privilege”, it’s only after a council officer discussed the press release they added legal privilege applies - no member of legal services was copied in and the communications was about a press release not the course case.
So factually the statement provided doesn't reference reality, and it conflicts with the cases referenced.
SECOND OBJECTION:
2. Identify and provide any recorded information where the FOI teams were
made aware that this consideration had taken place, and they were aware of
this practice.
What the council provided doesn’t satisfy the request, it’s not recorded information. The requestor is seeking records that clearly show the FOI team were aware of this practice and consideration to mark emails “Not subject to FOI”. From what has been provided by Steve Eccleston he had directed people to “I asked for potentially privileged emails involving lawyers to carry this header right at the start of the process”. Any record from around the start of the process informing the FOI team “that this consideration had taken place,”  and acknowledgement that FOI “they were aware of this practice.” Would be an ideal response for recorded information.
It seems in the email sent from the FOI team on 06 December 2019 they were not aware of this practice, and from my reading of the email seemed pretty aghast it was happening.
******************************
4. Please provide from  FS5074568 the request for information sent out from the FOI team to relevant departments and the responses received back with information held.
https://ico.org.uk/media/action-weve-tak...
I don’t think all the information has been provided In relation to the request, for brevity and to same time and space, the council made multiple assurances to the ICO in their investigation, and provide details. The emails provided don’t contain these the FOI team sourcing these responses.  I don’t see any recorded information provided from the information holders.
****************************
5. I'm having a hard time understanding the no information held. Could the FOI team expand on this on the internal review.
The email reference in 5 request  matches and is held information for FS5074568
Statement provided to 3 and 4 states "Information Management Team review all correspondence before it is
disclosed under FOI" and the statement that this request is about also claims "The exemptions used will always be thoroughly scrutinised by the council’s internal FOI team when handling these requests,"
Im looking for records of this thorough scrutiny applied to this record, as it was a responsive record, it matched the requestors information and matched the scope of an ICO investigation.
Yours sincerely,
Marcus Combie

Dear FOI,
The internal review for this request is 5 months overdue.
Since this request was about a carefully crafted press statement that was released only a couple of days after a news article about a FOI request I submitted.
Please indicate to the requestor when the internal review for this request will be completed.
If you cannot indicate when the request will be completed can the FOI team please indicate my options for escalation - is that with my already on going complaints or the ICO - what is my best method of remedy.
Yours sincerely,
Marcus Combie

Dear FOI,
I note your response to R Naylor on the What Do They Know website. Regarding R Naylor's request. REF  FOI 2020-21-2670
The council made a statement about my request:
"We have already provided copies of the information that we hold in
relation to emails with the subject "Covered by legal privilege and not
subject to FOI" and in relation to Legal Services informing officers of
this practice in our response to FOI 2019-20-1881" - This statement is false. The only materials the council provided were from Paul Bilington's inbox, and only materials that matched keywords such as Quito or Trees. The information provided to my request was not all the information the council holds. To be expounding the position in other requests is false.
The council also states:
"We have already provided copies of the information that we hold in
relation to emails with the subject "Covered by legal privilege and not
subject to FOI" and in relation to Legal Services informing officers of
this practice in our response to FOI 2019-20-1881, and therefore we
consider that your request is an attempt to reopen a matter which has
already been comprehensively addressed by the local authority."
- The requestor would categorically disagree with the council's positions this has been  been comprehensively addressed ". The internal review I submitted at the time and (still waiting on) explained clearly my objections to your response to FOI 2019-20-188
The internal review has not been complete.
Two complaints have been submitted.
One I was told by Kate Josephs on 18th March that  David Hollis, the Deputy Monitoring Officer will be leading the standards complaint against members and Eugene Walker, Executive Director Resources, will lead on the complaint against officers. Regarding the matter of marking emails "not subject to FOI" while an independent person is to look at the factual background.
I'm making this public so R Naylor can have visibility of my thoughts on this matter, I wish I had saw his request before so. could have posted this.
Furthermore, I'm chasing this internal review again. Please indicate to the requestor when it will be produced or my options for remedy.
Yours sincerely
Marcus Combie

Dear Mr Combie
We are responding to a complaint you made to the ICO (Reference
IC-98355-J1F7) regarding our response to you on 25 June 2021, relating to
two of your questions.
2. Identify and provide any recorded information where the FOI teams were
made aware that this consideration had taken place, and they were
aware of this practice.
Your reference was is to the use of the email subject header ‘legally
privileged not subject to FOI’. We hold an email from a council lawyer
dated 18 February 2020, which we have enclosed.
We have withheld personal information under Section 40(2) which exempts
information in response to a request if it is personal data belonging to
an individual other than yourself and it satisfies one of the conditions
listed in the legislation. The condition contained in section 40(3A)(a)
applies, that disclosure would breach one of the data protection
principles. The principle is that, “Personal data shall be processed
lawfully, fairly and in a transparent manner...” We do not consider that
disclosing this information to you, and consequently the public, is
necessary or justified in order to satisfy your information request and
the requirements of the FOIA. In the circumstances of this request there
is no strong legitimate interest that would override the prejudice to the
rights and freedoms of the data subjects. We have therefore taken the
decision that disclosing this information to you would be unlawful.
3. Identify how many officers were part of this consideration “there
might need to be a decision about future disclosure.”
We believe you are referring to a statement by Eugene Walker, Executive
Director of Resources at the council, in The Sheffield Star of 10 March
2020. Mr Walker stated: “…. officers marked some emails with the term
‘legally privileged not subject to FOI’ where they considered there might
need to be a decision about future disclosure.”
We have reviewed the emails relating to Operation Quito, which we released
to you on 6 December 2019. We can only identify one officer who marked
their emails in this way. We have not counted officers who have replied or
forwarded the email.
